This Court does it all the time and it has done it all the time in 1983 cases.
Monell is basically such a case where you are talking about a leave of absence policy.
That's something that you can review as policy.
Craig versus Boren was a 1983 case where you were talking, I believe, about age discrimination and when you could buy a beer.

Case after case after case, you're looking at a regulation, and this Court is not going to concern itself with the objective and subjective parts of qualified good faith immunity when you're reviewing policy itself.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Carlisle, let me carry the question I asked you before one step further.
I think I understand the answer, but I want to be sure.
Would you agree that if the facts that have been found here occurred today, that the city would be liable under 1983?

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: If we do accept, as I have only for the purposes of argument, that in some event, conduct can bind the city, and I think basically it can.

In other context, getting away from this case because I think the Court of Appeals was wrong when pressed to admit that, and although it's not salient to my theory as a whole, but I think that you can have situations possibly which may create a 1983 case for violation of federal laws where employee conduct, notwithstanding the non-application of the respondeat superior theory, could conceivably create entity liability.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And -- and specifically, this is such a case, unless we hold, that there is good faith immunity for the municipality.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: I'm -- I'm afraid I don't understand the question, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I -- I think I understand you to be arguing and in part admitting that if the facts we have before us occurred today, so there was no good faith immunity defense available, the city would be liable which -- the converse of which is that you are saying, in essence, that you are relying squarely on good faith immunity as the reason the city is not liable.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: I am, Your Honor, because I see absolutely no policy that I can rely on one way or the other.
Our Charter is silent as to policy.
We are looking only at conduct, conduct which merely because of the rank of Paul Roberts was treated as policy.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If that's true, may I ask you, because I really didn't find you addressing this very much.

Why should -- what --what is there in the law to support the notion that in a situation in which a city would otherwise be liable, it should be immune from liability because of the good faith of its officials?

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: Simply because you look at the nature of the cause of action.
I agree with opposing counsel that the qualified good faith immunity may be an ill chosen term because I think it relates to the cause of action.

If you are talking about a federal tort, as opposing counsel designates this case to be, then you are looking at a background of tort liability that includes concepts such as state of mind, proximate cause, cause and fact and duty.
I believe that the good faith immunity, if we can call it an immunity, which is, really, I think the defense on the merits, relates directly back to plaintiff's prima facie case on this federal tort.
And whether the -- I -- merely because --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: How does the --

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: -- the entity --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It's rather unusual to have an affirmative defense relate back to the prima facie case.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: Not at all, Your Honor.

Whether or not something is an affirmative defense is, as I understand civil procedure, made on a determination of whether or not it would be a permitted but disfavored defense, which this may well be, the convenience to the party's accessibility to evidence.
Quite often, we have a defense on the merits that is made an affirmative defense.

And incidentally, I do not know of this Court ever having held, and I think Wood versus Strickland can be held to the contrary or seen to the contrary that the good faith defense, as we know it, is, indeed, a -- an affirmative defense.
It's just kind of accepted as such, but I do not --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In fact, pecuniae then as to --

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: -- know that to be the case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- support your position on that.
Pecuniae against never as to support you on that.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Carlisle, the only injury alleged in this case, as I understand it, is stigma.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: As I understand it, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: The District Court found, also as I understand it, that there was no stigma.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, he --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Why -- why do you give your case away then?

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: Again, it's not the question presented on appeal.
I do reserve parts of that, Your Honor, in my last point relied on when I talk about the threshold question being a deprivation.
I do not believe a deprivation of liberty occurred in this case.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Well, why don't you stand on that?

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: Well, it was back [Laughs] a little bit further on my argument.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Which -- in -- in responding --

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: It is in my last point relied on, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: -- in responding to my Brother, Justice Stevens, I have understood you to concede that you (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: I do not concede that stigma is present in this case.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Certiorari (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The Court of Appeals found there was.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: The Court of Appeals found that there was a deprivation of liberty, that's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that there was stigma and --

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: There must be --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So -- so -- and to the extent that it's a respondent, you rely on the contrary.
You are in -- going contrary to the Court of Appeals --

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: In my last point --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- which is your privilege -- which is your privilege.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: Yes, and my last point relied on, Your Honor, I claim that there was no deprivation of liberty.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, in fairness to you then, Mr. Carlisle, you really want to withdraw your answer to one of my questions.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: I don't think so.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You don't really accept, for purposes of decision, the proposition that if this conduct occurred today, it would be liability against anybody.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: If it occurred today, Your Honor -- I -- I understand what you're saying.
There are two different ways of looking at it.
I feel that your question, in the abstract, as to the availability of a qualified immunity defense which I believe is lost if you're acting in the face of settled law.
That was the answer I had intended to give.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, I -- what I really meant to ask you, and I -- because there are so many issues that crisscrossing the case, is assuming you didn't have a qualified immunity defense at all because of the fact that it occurred today and there's no matter of unsettled law or anything else, just on the basic facts of the case, I was asking you whether or not you were contending that there would be no liability anyway.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: There would be none, under my last point relied on.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because of the argument that there's not a --

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: I do not believe that plaintiff has established threshold question of deprivation of liberty.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And that's because you don't regard these -- these comments as stigma, is that it?

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: They -- they were not stigmatizing in connection with the discharge, Your Honor, which you must --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is that because (a) we're not stigmatizing or (b) we're not in connection with the discharge?

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: Primarily, they were not in connection with the discharge, although I think the District Court was correct in -- in finding, and he was the trier of fact, that the plaintiff's name was cleared by the return of a no --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, that's still a different (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: -- true bill by the grand jury.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You've got three possible arguments.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: Yes, you do.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: One, not stigma and two, not in connection and three, they've been cured.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: I have -- I have --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I want to know which are you relying on here.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: I have conceded, for the purposes of argument, all along that the robust comments of Paul Roberts were stigmatizing.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Alright, and do you -- but you deny that they are in connection with the discharge.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: I certainly do, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You also argue that they were cured in any event.

turn.speaker: richard_g_carlisle
turn.label: Mr. Richard G. Carlisle
turn.text: I do, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
We'll hear arguments next in Illinois against Vitale.
